questions.question_text:
Although an organization has sufficient capacity within the on-premises VMware SDDC, the CTO has decided to evolve the public cloud strategy into a “Right Cloud First” strategy. To support this, the administrator has suggested the use of vRealize Automation to provide a consistent portal with a multi-cloud service catalog to enable the users to use self-service to deploy workloads into different clouds. The administrator needs to configure cloud accounts for public clouds to support the new strategy.

Which two of the public clouds are supported platforms? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
vRealize Automation supports multiple public clouds, allowing customers to deploy workloads to different cloud platforms using a single, consistent portal. The public clouds that are supported by vRealize Automation include:

A. Microsoft Azure
C. Google Cloud Platform

Therefore, the correct answers are A and C. IBM Cloud, Oracle Cloud, and OVH Cloud are not currently supported as public cloud platforms in vRealize Automation. However, it is always recommended to check the latest compatibility matrix to confirm the support status of any public cloud platform.

questions.question_text:
An administrator configures cloud accounts for vSphere, Amazon Web Services and Google Cloud Platform. Each public cloud account has a single region configured, with a single cloud zone associated with each. Company policy states that all development workloads should be deployed to the public cloud and all production workloads should be deployed to vSphere. The administrator wants to ensure that when creating cloud templates for this project an appropriate constraint tag is specified to meet the placement policy and that App-Dev users are allowed to select whether to deploy the machine to production or development.
The tagging strategy states that development environments should be tagged with `dev` and production environments should be tagged `prod`.
Which two actions should the administrator take to ensure the objective is met? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Add a capability tag to each public cloud zone, using env:dev as the key/value pair.
choices.E: Add a capability tag to each public cloud zone, using env:prod as the key/value pair.
choices.D: Add a capability tag to each vSphere cloud zone, using env:prod as the key/value pair.
choices.A: Add a capability tag to each cloud account, using env:prod as the key/value pair.
choices.C: Add a capability tag to each vSphere cloud zone, using env:dev as the key/value pair.

discussion.content:
This question seems to be more an IQ test than anything else. It's always important to read the questions carefully, and this question simply requires that is done. 

We use capability tags to guide workload placement. The question requires Prod workloads go on VSphere and Dev workloads go on Cloud. So we choose the only two answers that fit these requirements. 

B and D are correct.

questions.question_text:
After collecting a log bundle using the vracli CLI command, the resulting .tar file contains many paths and files.

Where will the administrator find the logs related specifically to the embedded vRealize Orchestrator?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer is B.

The key here is 'Embedded vRO', so its going to have a prelude file path. 

See this: https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Automation/8.11/Administering/GUID-EB314825-845A-4F31-8155-53F99F0B7B3C.html

Selected Answer: B
The embedded vRealize Orchestrator in vRealize Automation is deployed as a container within the vRealize Automation appliance. Therefore, to find the logs related specifically to the embedded vRealize Orchestrator in the collected log bundle, the administrator needs to look for the relevant log files within the container.

The log files related to the embedded vRealize Orchestrator in vRealize Automation are typically located in the container with the prefix "/pods/prelude/vco-app-". Therefore, the correct answer is B. /pods/prelude/vco-app-. The relevant log files can be found within this directory in the collected log bundle.
